FUTL, FUTL General
44.1 FUTL General
� General Information
All modern vehicles have a tank display and a reserve signal display. For the tank leakage diagnosis additionally
a ?ller cap ?ag is needed. Some OBD diagnoses need informations about the fuel level and the condition of
the ?ller cap signal.
The task of the aggregate FUTL is it to evaluate the fuel level sensor, determine the reserve signal and deter-
mine the ?ller cap condition.
This aggregate has two input signal variants, CAN and PIN.
44.1.1 Architecture Overview
The following picture shows the function architecture of FUTL. The picture shows the individual dependence
on the moduls.

FUTL, FUTL General
44.1.2 Description of the containing functions
? Fuel tank level for CAN inputs
This modul is a placeholder and must be used for the CAN signal inputs. It is a interface between the AGGR
FUTL and die CAN interface. All signals are read form CAN interface for the AGGR FUTL. This modul can read
one or two fuel tank level signals. The modul is be able to read a reserve signal and a ?ller cap signal. The
number of the input signals are con?gurable.
A diagnosis is made about the CAN fuel tank level sensor signal.
The output is a ?x interface, it is independent of the number of the input signals.
? Fuel signal calculation
The fuel level calculation is made in this modul. This modul is be able to handle one or two fuel tank level input
signals (saddle tank). In the same way this modul calculates the reserve signal and recognizes a refueling and
defueling.
? Fuel tank level functional diagnosis
This modul checks the plausibility of the fuel level sensor(s). It is be able to do this for one or two fuel sensor
signals. One part of the diagnosis detects an error if sensor signal be stuck. The other part compare the fuel
level signal with the fuel consumption of the engine and set an error if the difference to big.
Also all error ?ag are summarized in this modul.
? Fuel signal outputs
This modul is a placeholder for the output signals to other components or other ECUs. The calculated signals
of the AGGR are given out about this modul.

44.3.1.1.1 Variant Coding of the Fuel Sensor
With the calibration data LC_FTL_NR_SENS it is possible to make a variant coding of the fuel tank
level signals. If the condition NC_FTL_NR_SENS = 2, then it is possible to choose the number of FTL
sensors with LC_STL_NR_SENS 0= 1 FTL sensor, 1= 2 FTL sensor.

If the condition NC_FTL_NR_SENS = 2, then it is possible to choose the number of FTL
sensors with LC_STL_NR_SENS 0= 1 FTL sensor, 1= 2 FTL sensor.
In case we have two separate fuel tank sensors (NC_FTL_NR_SENS = 2 AND FTL_NR_SENS = 2)
then
i = 1, for fuel tank sensor 1
i = 2, for fuel tank sensor 2
otherwise (NC_FTL_NR_SENS != 2 OR (NC_FTL_NR_SENS = 2 AND FTL_NR_SENS = 1))
i = 1, for single fuel tank sensor

44.3.2.1 Fuel Tank level temporary value

times to be provided to the ECU. For that we wait a certain time before calculating the FTL to ensure that
the value given is valid. During that time FTL_MMV_LPF ,FTL_MMV_AV and FTL_STUCK_LPF are initialized
with FTL_BAS value.

44.3.2.2 Fuel Tank Level Calculation
General information:
REMARK :
The following calibration that are only used for 2 sensors con?guration shall not be de?ned in case of only one
sensor (NC_FTL_NR_SENS = 1) :
C_FTL_1_FOL, C_FTL_2_THD, C_FTL_1_BOL, C_FTL_2_BOL, ID_T_FTL_CHG, LDP_FTL_STATE_PRED_ID_T_FTL_CHG,
C_FTL_1_MAX
General information:
This speci?cation is intended to document the algorithm used for determining the amount of fuel remaining
in the fuel tanks of a dual fuel tank system ( saddlebag tank) as well as a single fuel tank system. For single
fuel tank applications, the secondary fuel tank parameters must be calibrated to 0 and the Primary Tank Full
Threshold calibration parameter must be bigger than or equal to the Primary Tank Rated Capacity calibration
parameter. For dual fuel tank applications, it is assumed that the transfer of fuel is consumed from the primary
tank while a transfer pump continuously transfers fuel from the secondary tank to the primary tank. It seems
that fuel is consumed from the secondary tank before the primary tank.
In general, the total fuel volume can be determined by adding the amount of fuel in the two tanks together.
The total fuel volume can be accurately determined when the fuel is measurable in each of the tanks.

FUTL, Fuel signal calculation
Unfortunately, in some projects there are certain cases where one or both tanks haven t measurable fuel in
the tanks. When this occurs, a fuel consumption calculation is used over special cases.
It is also necessary to detect a dynamic fuel tank level and a low fuel tank level (<20% for OBD purpose). This
task will be performed by this function, too.
This module detected also refueling or defueling of the fuel tank.
In case we have two separate fuel tank sensors (NC_FTL_NR_SENS = 2 AND FTL_NR_SENS = 2) then
i = 1, for fuel tank sensor 1
i = 2, for fuel tank sensor 2
otherwise (NC_FTL_NR_SENS != 2 OR (NC_FTL_NR_SENS = 2 AND FTL_NR_SENS = 1))
i = 1, for single fuel tank sensor
Description:
Dual Fuel Tank - Fuel Volume Determination
Figure 44.3.13:
Sens1= Primary Tank Fuel Volume (Voltage vs. Fuel Volume calibration table)
B= Primary Tank Full Threshold (Fuel Volume calibration parameter)
C= Secondary Tank Empty Threshold (Fuel Volume calibration parameter)
Sens2= Secondary Tank Fuel Volume (Voltage vs. Fuel Volume calibration table)
E= Primary Tank Rated Capacity (Fuel Volume calibration parameter)
F= Primary Tank Rated Capacity + Secondary Tank Rated Capacity (Fuel Volume calibration parameter)
G= Primary Tank Unusable + Secondary Tank Unusable (for EVAP calc Fuel Volume calibration parameter)
H= Primary Tank lower Threshold (Fuel Volume calibration parameter)
J= Secondary Tank Estimate Threshold (Fuel Volume calibration parameter) (same as C on most applica-
tions)

FUTL, Fuel signal calculation
K= Secondary Tank rated capacity (Fuel Volume calibration parameter)
Diagnostics:
If Sens1<H AND Sens2>C (Primary Tank almost empty AND Secondary Tank above empty threshold)
Fuel Volume = Sens2 (failure the fuel level to the display because the transfer pump failed)
Case 1: Sens1>B AND Sens2>J (Primary Tank Full AND Secondary Tank Above Estimate Threshold)
Fuel Volume = E + Sens2
Case 2: Sens1>B AND Sens2<J (Primary Tank Full AND Secondary Tank Below Estimate Threshold)
Fuel Volume = E + Sens2 (FTL display has ca � gradient or a dead band )
Case 3: Sens1<B AND Sens2>C (Primary Tank Not Full AND Secondary Tank Above Empty Threshold)
Fuel Volume = Sens1 + Sens2
Case 4: Sens1<B AND Sens2<C (Primary Tank Not Full AND Secondary Tank Below Empty Threshold)
Fuel Volume = Sens1

as the base for the consecutive calculations.

Figure 44.3.17:
44.3.2.2.2.1.1 OPM/CLC_FTL_VOL/CLC_FTL_STATE/TWO_SEN_SYS/CLC_FTL_STATE/NO_ERR_STATE
If either sensor has error, go to default state 3, in which the total fuel volume is calculated by adding both tank
fuel so as to allow tank leak detection functions to continue to running.
Diagnostic check
Case 0: Primary tank is almost empty and second tank above empty threshold.
Case 1: Primary tank is full and second tank above estimate threshold.
Case 2: Primary tank is full and second tank below estimate threshold.
Case 3: Primary tank is not full and second tank above empty threshold.
Case 4: Primary tank is not full and second tank below empty threshold.

44.3.2.2.2.1.2 FTL state transition determination
A transition from one state to another is ?ltered such that conditions for entering the new state must be
satis?ed for ID_T_FTL_CHG(FTL_STATE_PRED) continuous seconds before changing to the new state. However,
FTL_STATE must be set with FTL_STATE_PRED upon activation as part of initialization in order for the gauge
to display correct value faster.
FTL Internal Timer Management
As soon as FTL_STATE_PRED changes, reset internal timer. Then the timer free-rolls till reach the maximum
value and latches it.

44.3.3.2 Refueling and Defueling recognition
The fuel tank level signal FTL_MMV_VOL is used to detected a refueling or defueling. At ignition on the function
get the last fuel tank level value from the NVRAM. So the function can detected a refueling / defueling by
ignition off. This is the normal case.
The refueling / defueling is detected when vehicle speed is below a threshold or when the time elapsed since
last activation is bigger than a threshold. When this time has elapsed the actual fuel tanl value is taken into
account for new comparison for refueling / defueling detection.

DLY_VS_STOP_REFU. This will allow fuel stabilization in tank before refueling detection activation.

(e.g. <8 l). The variable LV_FRS serves as an additional information for various OBD II diagnosis. LV_FRS = true
means low fuel is detected/ active.

44.4.2.1 Calculation in 1 sec grid
With ignition key on (LV_IGK = true) and no failure active (LV_FRS_ERR_CAN = false) the signal by instrument
cluster (ICL) is taken directly for evaluation of LV_FRS.
If an adjustable time after ignition key on is elapsed (T_DLY_FRS_DIAG_CAN = 0 sec) and an CAN error is
detected (LV_FRS_ERR_CAN = true) the FRS signal is set to high (LV_FRS = 1).
In case of ignition is switched off (LV_IGK = false) the last valid FRS signal is kept.

� General Information
Information of electrical error of fuel tank level sensors. The number of sensors is depending on the vehicle

� Application Conditions

for i = 0 to NC_NR_FTL_SENS

FTL_SENS_EL[i]>)
Other outputs are initialized by Error Management
EndFor
Activation: always

Recurrence: 100ms
� Function Description
Electrical diagnosis of 1st FTL sensor :
#IF(NC_NR_FTL_SENS > 0)
#THEN
IF LV_INH_FTL_SENS_EL[0] = 0 AND bit 0 of CLF_FTL_SENS_EL = 1
THEN LV_CDN_DIAG_TMP = 1
ELSE LV_CDN_DIAG_TMP = 0
ENDIF
IF LV_CDN_DIAG_TMP = 1
THEN IF CAN_STATE_ERR_FTL_SENS_1 = 1 // SCG
THEN ERR_SYM_TMP = SYM_1
ELSE IF CAN_STATE_ERR_FTL_SENS_1 = 8 // SCP/OC
THEN ERR_SYM_TMP = SYM_0
ELSE IF CAN_STATE_ERR_FTL_SENS_1 = 11 // signal not plausible

For failure and error management treatment the anti-bounce mechanism is called
with the parameters LV_CDN_DIAG_TMP and ERR_SYM_TMP
ACTION_ERRM_FilterSymptom(IN <FTL_SENS_EL[0]>, IN <LV_CDN_DIAG_TMP>, IN <ERR_
SYM_TMP>, IN <C_ABC_INC_FTL_SENS_EL>, IN <1>, IN <C_ABC_MAX_FTL_SENS_EL>, OUT
<LV_ERR_FTL_SENS_EL[0] >)
This algorithm determines:
ERR_SYM_FTL_SENS_EL[0] (detected error symptom)

LV_CDN_DIAG_FTL_SENS_EL[0] (Diagnosis condition information)
LV_END_DIAG_FTL_SENS_EL[0] (End of diagnosis information)
#ENDIF

Initialisation: all outputs = 0
Activation: always

� Function Description
Fuel tank level sensor diagnosis has to be inhibited by FARM,
For i=0 to NC_NR_FTL_SENS
IF ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(NC_FID_ERR_FTL_EL[i]) = TRUE
AND LC_FTL_DIAG_INH = 0
THEN

ELSE
LV_INH_FTL_SENS_EL[i] = 1
ENDIF
EndFor

44.7.2.2.1.1.1.3.1 Fuel tank level stuck symptom determination
The fuel tank level signal can be detected as stuck with raw electrical from sensor FTL_BAS_EL_R or via the con-
verted value in liter. The fuel tank level value can determined as stuck if the raw signal stay in a window de?ned
by the hysteresis +- C_FTL_MMV_xxx_HYS and the fuel tank level mean value memorized.

This image displays an architectural Simulink-like diagram, specifically for a "Fuel signal calculation" (FUTL) system, common in automotive embedded control units.

## Function

The primary function of this system is to perform comprehensive fuel signal calculations. It integrates various sensor inputs, control signals, and internal states to produce a wide array of fuel-related outputs. The system operates at multiple recurrences (100ms and 1s) and includes initialization, cyclic calculations, and state feedback mechanisms to ensure accurate and dynamic fuel management and diagnostics.

## Inputs

The system receives several key inputs:

**Raw Sensor/External Inputs (Bundled into `<input>` bus):**
*   `<FCO_SUM_FTL>`
*   `<FTL_BAS>`
*   `<FTL_BAS_EL_R>`
*   `<FTL_CAN_REL>`
*   `<LV_FRS_SWI>`
*   `<LV_IGK>`
*   `<NG_FRS_SWI>`
*   `<NC_FTL_NR_SENS>`
*   `<VS>`

**Control Signals (from Recurrence/Init Block):**
*   `fc_ini`: Initialization trigger.
*   `fc_OPM_100MS`: Trigger for operations recurring every 100 milliseconds.
*   `fc_OPM_1S`: Trigger for operations recurring every 1 second.

**Internal Feedback Input:**
*   `<feedback>`: A signal representing the system's internal state or outputs from a previous cycle, fed back into the processing blocks for sequential logic or stateful calculations.

## Outputs

The system produces a comprehensive set of fuel-related outputs:

*   `<FTL>`
*   `<FTL_DEFU>`
*   `<FTL_MMV>`
*   `<FTL_MMV_AV>`
*   `<FTL_MMV_LPF>`
*   `<FTL_MMV_VOL>`
*   `<FTL_NR_SENS>`
*   `<FTL_REFU>`
*   `<FTL_STUCK_EL_LPF>`
*   `<FTL_STUCK_LPF>`
*   `<FTL_TOT>`
*   `<LV_FTL_DYN>`
*   `<LV_FTL_IGK_CYC_REFU_DEFU>`
*   `<LV_FTL_OBD_INH_L>`
*   `<LV_FTL_RGN_H>`
*   `<LV_T_FTL_INI>`
*   `<STATE_FTL_REFU_DEFU>`
*   `<T_FTL_REFU_DIAG>`
*   `[feedback]`: An output signal representing the system's internal state, potentially for logging or use by other external modules.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow describes how the system processes its inputs to generate the outputs:

1.  **Configuration and Control Signal Generation:**
    *   The top-level orange block defines the system's operational recurrence (100ms, 1s) and initialization conditions (RST, IGKON, NVMIN, NVMSTO, NVMRES).
    *   Based on these settings, it generates control signals: `fc_ini` (for initialization), `fc_OPM_100MS` (for 100ms tasks), and `fc_OPM_1S` (for 1s tasks).

2.  **Input Bundling:**
    *   Multiple raw input signals from various sources (e.g., sensors, other ECUs) are gathered and bundled into an `input` bus.

3.  **Initialization Phase (INI - X.1 Block):**
    *   When triggered by the `fc_ini` signal, the `INI` block performs initialization.
    *   It takes the `input` bus and the `feedback` signal (representing prior state) to set up initial conditions, variables, or states for the fuel calculation.
    *   Its output (`ini`) provides these initialized values to the subsequent cyclic operation blocks.

4.  **100ms Cyclic Operation (OPM_100MS - X.2 Block):**
    *   This block executes its internal function (`fc()`) every 100 milliseconds, triggered by `fc_OPM_100MS`.
    *   It receives the current `input` bus, the `ini` values from the initialization block, and the `feedback` signal (state from the previous cycle).
    *   It performs calculations that require higher update frequency, contributing to a portion of the system's overall outputs. The outputs of this block are labeled `opm_100ms`.

5.

*   It receives the current `input` bus, the `ini` values from the initialization block, and the `feedback` signal (state from the previous cycle).
    *   It performs calculations that require higher update frequency, contributing to a portion of the system's overall outputs. The outputs of this block are labeled `opm_100ms`.

5.  **1s Cyclic Operation (OPM_1S - X.3 Block):**
    *   This block executes its internal function (`fc()`) every 1 second, triggered by `fc_OPM_1S`.
    *   Similar to the 100ms block, it receives the current `input` bus, the `ini` values, and the `feedback` signal.
    *   It performs calculations that can be updated less frequently, possibly involving diagnostics, long-term averages, or specific state updates. The outputs of this block are labeled `opm_1s`.

6.  **Output Generation and Feedback Loop:**
    *   The processed results from the `OPM_100MS` and `OPM_1S` blocks (and implicitly, the `INI` block's influence via `ini` signal) are combined and mapped to the extensive list of output signals (e.g., `<FTL>`, `<FTL_DEFU>`, etc.).
    *   A portion of the internal computed state or specific outputs are consolidated into the `[feedback]` signal. This signal is then routed back as an input to the `INI`, `OPM_100MS`, and `OPM_1S` blocks, closing the feedback loop and enabling the system to maintain and update its internal state across consecutive operational cycles. This is critical for functions like estimations, filtering, and state-dependent logic.

This image is a Simulink diagram.

## Function
This Simulink diagram, titled "44.3.1 Initialization" and associated with "FUTL. Fuel signal calculation", describes the primary initialization sequence for various system states, particularly those related to fuel signal processing and non-volatile memory management. Its main function is to establish the initial operating conditions and persistent data states upon system startup or reset, bundling these critical initial values into a structured bus output.

## Inputs
The diagram receives several control and data input signals:

*   **`fc_ini`**: A main function-call trigger signal, indicating the overall initialization event.
*   **`<fc_RST>`**: A flag or trigger for a system reset operation.
*   **`<FTL_MMV_REFU_VS_STOP>` (feedback)**: A feedback signal representing the current Fuel Minimum Measured Value Refuel Versus Stop status, used during reset.
*   **`<fc_IGKON>`**: A flag or trigger indicating the ignition ON state.
*   **`<fc_NVMINI>`**: A flag or trigger for non-volatile memory initialization.
*   **`<fc_NVMRES>`**: A flag or trigger for non-volatile memory reset.
*   **`<fc_NVMSTO>`**: A flag or trigger for non-volatile memory storage operations.
*   **NVMY_STO Specific Inputs (from `<Input>` and `<feedback>` blocks)**: A collection of fuel-related data signals intended for non-volatile storage:
    *   `<FCO_SUM_FTL>`
    *   `<FTL_MMV_DC>`
    *   `<LV_FTL_RGN_H>`
    *   `<FCO_SUM_REFU_VS_STOP>`
    *   `<FTL_MMV_REFU_VS_STOP>` (another instance, likely for the NVMY_STO block)
    *   `<LV_REFU_DC_END>`
    *   `<FTL_MMV_DC_PREV>`

## Outputs
The primary output of this subsystem is a single bus containing the initialized states:

*   **`ini`**: A bus signal that consolidates the outputs from the `RST`, `IGK_ON`, `NVMY_INI`, and `NVMY_RES` blocks.

The individual elements of this bus are:
    *   `FTL_MMV_REFU_VS_STOP` (initialized value from RST block)
    *   `igk_on` (initialized value from IGK_ON block)
    *   `nvmini` (status from NVMY_INI block)
    *   `nvmy_res` (status from NVMY_RES block)

Additionally, the `NVMY_STO` block has several output signals which represent the stored/retrieved values, but these are not part of the final `ini` bus:
*   `<FCO_SUM_FTL>`
*   `<FTL_MMV_DC>`
*   `<LV_FTL_RGN_H>`
*   `<FCO_SUM_REFU_VS_STOP>`
*   `<FTL_MMV_REFU_VS_STOP>`
*   `<LV_REFU_DC_END>`
*   `<FTL_MMV_DC_PREV>`

## Logic Flow

The initialization logic proceeds in a parallel fashion, orchestrated by implicit or explicit triggers, and culminates in a consolidated output bus:

1.  **Overall Initialization Trigger:** The `fc_ini` input (labeled '1' on the left) acts as the high-level trigger for the entire initialization process. While not directly connected to the individual `fc()` blocks, it implies that when `fc_ini` is active, the associated control signals (`<fc_RST>`, `<fc_IGKON>`, etc.) are also asserted to initiate their respective functions.

2.  **Parallel Subsystem Execution:**
    *   **Reset (RST X.1.1):** When triggered by `<fc_RST>`, this block executes its `fc()` logic. It takes the `FTL_MMV_REFU_VS_STOP` feedback signal as an input, potentially to determine the initial state of this value after a reset. Its output, `FTL_MMV_REFU_VS_STOP`, represents the initialized or reset value of this status.
    *   **Ignition ON (IGK_ON X.1.2):** Triggered by `<fc_IGKON>`, this block's `fc()` logic processes the ignition status. It outputs `igk_on`, representing the initialized state of the ignition flag.
    *   **NVM Initialization (NVMY_INI X.1.3):** Triggered by `<fc_NVMINI>`, this block's `fc()` logic handles the initialization routines for the non-volatile memory (NVM). This might involve checking NVM integrity or loading default settings. It outputs `nvmini`, indicating the status or result of NVM initialization.
    *   **NVM Reset (NVMY_RES X.1.4):** Triggered by `<fc_NVMRES>`, this block's `fc()` logic executes NVM reset procedures, which could involve clearing certain NVM regions. It outputs `nvmy_res`, indicating the status or result of the NVM reset.
    *   **NVM Storage (NVMY_STO X.1.5):** Triggered by `<fc_NVMSTO>`, this block's `fc()` logic manages the persistent storage and retrieval of various fuel-related data. It receives current system values (from `<Input>` and `<feedback>` blocks) to store them in NVM, and it outputs the stored or retrieved values. This block's outputs are not part of the final `ini` bus, suggesting its role is to set up persistent states for other modules, rather than directly contribute to the *initialization status* bus.

3.  **Bus Consolidation:** The initialized outputs from the `RST`, `IGK_ON`, `NVMY_INI`, and `NVMY_RES` blocks (`FTL_MMV_REFU_VS_STOP`, `igk_on`, `nvmini`, `nvmy_res`) are fed into a `BusMerge` block (V.6.5).

4.  **Final Output:** The `BusMerge` block combines these individual signals into a single, structured bus named `ini`, which is then provided as the output of this initialization subsystem. This consolidated bus provides a comprehensive initial state snapshot to other parts of the "FUTL. Fuel signal calculation" system.

This image is indeed a Simulink-like diagram, likely representing a subsystem or function within an automotive ECU software. The notation and block types are consistent with Simulink or TargetLink models used for embedded control development.

## Function
The primary function of this Simulink diagram is the **Initialization at Reset for Fuel Signal Calculation (FUTL)**. It configures and assigns initial values to various internal variables and states related to fuel tank level (FTL) measurement, refueling detection, and associated diagnostic flags when the system undergoes a reset. It also handles variant coding for the number of fuel sensors.

## Inputs
In the context of an initialization diagram, "inputs" are primarily configuration parameters or constants that determine the initial values.

*   **Configuration Parameters / Variant Coding:**
    *   `<FTL_NR_SENS>`: Number of Fuel Tank Sensors (determined by `VAR_COD` block, likely a variant coding input, referred to as `LC_FTL_NR_SENS` in the accompanying text).
    *   `C_T_FTL_REFU_DIAG_MAX`: Calibration parameter for maximum refueling diagnostic time.
    *   `C_T_REFU_DEF_ACT`: Calibration parameter for default refueling activity.
    *   `NC_FTL_NR_SENS`: Number of Fuel Tank Sensors (used for array sizing, derived from `LC_FTL_NR_SENS` in the text).

*   **Constant Initial Values (hardcoded in the diagram):**
    *   `0`: Used to initialize many signals (e.g., `<FTL>`, `<FTL_MMV>`, `<FTL_DEF_REFU>`).
    *   `3`: Used to initialize `<FTL_STATE>` and `<FTL_STATE_PRED>`.
    *   `TRUE`: Used to initialize `<LV_FTL_FAST_REQ>` and `<LV_VS_STOP_REFU>`.
    *   `FALSE`: Used to initialize `<LV_FTL_OBD_INH_L>`, `<LV_FTL_INL>`, `<LV_FTL_IGK_CYC_REFU_DEF_REFU>`, `<LV_REFU_DC_END>`, `<LV_FTL_REFU_DEF_ACT>`.
    *   `NONE`: Used to initialize `STATE_FTL_REFU_DEF_REFU`.

## Outputs
The outputs are the internal system variables and signals that are initialized by this diagram at reset.

*   `<FTL>`: Fuel Tank Level.
*   `<FTL_MMV>`: Fuel Tank Level Mass Moving Value.
*   `<FTL_MMV_VOL>`: Fuel Tank Level Mass Moving Volume.
*   `<FTL_STATE>`: Fuel Tank Level State.
*   `<FTL_STATE_PRED>`: Predicted Fuel Tank Level State.
*   `<FTL_TOT>`: Total Fuel Tank Level.
*   `<LV_FTL_FAST_REQ>`: Level Fuel Tank Level Fast Request flag.
*   `<LV_FTL_OBD_INH_L>`: Level Fuel Tank Level OBD Inhibit Low flag.
*   `<LV_FTL_INL>`: Level Fuel Tank Level Inlet flag.
*   `<T_FTL_INL>`: Time Fuel Tank Level Inlet.
*   `<T_FTL_STATE_DLY>`: Time Fuel Tank Level State Delay.
*   `<T_FTL_TOT_HYS>`: Time Fuel Tank Level Total Hysteresis.
*   `<VS_MMV>`: Vehicle Speed Mass Moving Value.
*   `<FTL_MMV_AV>`: Fuel Tank Level Mass Moving Average (array, size depends on `NC_FTL_NR_SENS`).
*   `<FTL_MMV_LPF>`: Fuel Tank Level Mass Moving Low-Pass Filtered value (array, size depends on `NC_FTL_NR_SENS`).
*   `<FTL_STUCK_LPF>`: Fuel Tank Level Stuck Low-Pass Filtered value (array, size depends on `NC_FTL_NR_SENS`).
*   `<FTL_STUCK_EL_LPF>`: Fuel Tank Level Stuck Electrical Low-Pass Filtered value (array, size depends on `NC_FTL_NR_SENS`).
*   `<FTL_DEF_REFU>`: Fuel Tank Level Default Refueling flag.
*   `<FTL_REFU>`: Fuel Tank Level Refueling flag.
*   `<LV_FTL_IGK_CYC_REFU_DEF_REFU>`: Level Fuel Tank Level Ignition Cycle Refueling Default Refueling flag.
*   `STATE_FTL_REFU_DEF_REFU`: State Fuel Tank Level Refueling Default Refueling.
*   `<T_FTL_MMV_OLD_SET>`: Time Fuel Tank Level Mass Moving Old Set.
*   `<T_FTL_REFU_DIAG>`: Time Fuel Tank Level Refueling Diagnostic.

*   `<LV_FTL_IGK_CYC_REFU_DEF_REFU>`: Level Fuel Tank Level Ignition Cycle Refueling Default Refueling flag.
*   `STATE_FTL_REFU_DEF_REFU`: State Fuel Tank Level Refueling Default Refueling.
*   `<T_FTL_MMV_OLD_SET>`: Time Fuel Tank Level Mass Moving Old Set.
*   `<T_FTL_REFU_DIAG>`: Time Fuel Tank Level Refueling Diagnostic.
*   `<LV_REFU_DC_END>`: Level Refueling Downstream Cylinder End flag.
*   `<LV_VS_STOP_REFU>`: Level Vehicle Speed Stop Refueling flag.
*   `<LV_FTL_REFU_DEF_ACT>`: Level Fuel Tank Level Refueling Default Activity flag.
*   `<T_DLY_VS_STOP_REFU>`: Time Delay Vehicle Speed Stop Refueling.
*   `<FTL_MMV_REFU_VS_STOP>`: Fuel Tank Level Mass Moving Refueling Vehicle Speed Stop.
*   `<FTL_REFU_DEF_REFU>`: Fuel Tank Level Refueling Default Refueling.
*   `<FCO_SUM_REFU_VS_STOP>`: Fuel Cut Off Sum Refueling Vehicle Speed Stop.
*   `<T_REFU_DEF_ACT>`: Time Refueling Default Activity.
*   `rst`: A merged bus containing one or more of the above initialized signals, acting as the overall reset output from this functional block.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Left Block - General FTL Initialization:** A series of constant blocks on the left side (values 0, 3, TRUE, FALSE) are directly connected to various `<FTL_...>` and `<LV_...>` signals. This initializes these fuel tank level related variables and flags to safe or default states immediately upon system reset. For instance, `<FTL>` and `<VS_MMV>` are set to 0, `<FTL_STATE>` is set to 3, and `<LV_FTL_FAST_REQ>` is set to TRUE.

2.  **Array Initialization (Sensor Variants):** Below the general FTL initialization, four array initialization blocks are shown, e.g., `[NC_FTL_NR_SENS] array`. These blocks initialize arrays such as `<FTL_MMV_AV>`, `<FTL_MMV_LPF>`, `<FTL_STUCK_LPF>`, and `<FTL_STUCK_EL_LPF>`. The size of these arrays (and thus the number of elements initialized) is determined by the input `NC_FTL_NR_SENS`, which represents the number of fuel tank sensors. The accompanying text explains that `LC_FTL_NR_SENS = 2` means two fuel tank sensors, and other values mean a single sensor. This ensures the correct number of array elements are initialized based on the vehicle's configuration.

3.  **Right Block - Refueling and Diagnostic FTL Initialization:** Similar to the left block, another series of constant blocks on the right initializes signals predominantly related to refueling (`<FTL_REFU>`, `<LV_REFU_DC_END>`) and diagnostic flags (`<LV_FTL_IGK_CYC_REFU_DEF_REFU>`). These are set to default values (0, FALSE, TRUE, NONE) at reset.

4.  **Configuration Parameter Handling:** Blocks like `VAR_COD <FTL_NR_SENS>` and constants like `C_T_FTL_REFU_DIAG_MAX` and `C_T_REFU_DEF_ACT` represent configuration or calibration parameters. 4.  Consolidate these key pieces of information into a comprehensive output bus representing the system's confidence or status regarding the two fuel sensors.

The system is specifically designed to handle scenarios where either sensor might have an error, defaulting to a specific state (State 3) to allow continuous tank leak detection.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow can be described in two interconnected parts:

### Part 1: Filter Constant Selection Logic (Figure 44.3.26 - Subsystem `FTL_TOT_HYS_CLC`)

This subsystem calculates `LV_FTL_FAST_REQ` and `T_FTL_TOT_HYS`.

1.  **Fast Filter Request (`LV_FTL_FAST_REQ`) Calculation:**
    *   The current `FTL_TOT` is continuously compared against two thresholds: `C_FTL_TOT_HYS_L` and `C_FTL_TOT_HYS_H`.
    *   If `FTL_TOT` drops below `C_FTL_TOT_HYS_L`, a "SET" signal is generated.
    *   If `FTL_TOT` rises above `C_FTL_TOT_HYS_H`, a "RESET" signal is generated.

This implements a standard hysteresis: once `LV_FTL_FAST_REQ` is set, it remains true until `FTL_TOT` crosses the upper threshold, and vice-versa.

2.  **Total Hysteresis Flag (`T_FTL_TOT_HYS`) Calculation:**
    *   The current `LV_FTL_FAST_REQ` (output of the SR-FlipFlop) is fed into an OR gate (V.6.7).

    *   A constant `0` (representing logical FALSE) is also an input to the OR gate, which does not affect the logical outcome.
    *   The output of the OR gate determines the current `T_FTL_TOT_HYS`. This means `T_FTL_TOT_HYS` becomes TRUE if `LV_FTL_FAST_REQ` is TRUE, OR if `T_FTL_TOT_HYS` was already TRUE in the previous step. This makes `T_FTL_TOT_HYS` a "sticky" flag: once it becomes TRUE, it will remain TRUE indefinitely within this subsystem's logic, unless explicitly reset by an external mechanism not shown.

## Function

The primary function of this system is to manage, initialize, and calculate the "Fuel Reserve Signal" (`opm` or `FUTL`) within an automotive Electronic Control Unit (ECU). It handles signal initialization during ECU resets and ignition key transitions, and continuously calculates the fuel reserve status based on ignition state, CAN bus communication errors, and time delays. The goal is to provide a reliable fuel reserve indication to the driver, even under fault conditions.

## Inputs

The system takes several key inputs:

*   **`LV_IGK`**: (Boolean) Represents the status of the ignition key. `TRUE` typically means ignition is ON, `FALSE` means ignition is OFF.
*   **`LV_FRS_ERR_CAN`**: (Boolean) Indicates if an error is detected in the Fuel Reserve Signal received via the CAN bus. `TRUE` means an error is present.

## Inputs

The system takes several key inputs:

*   **`LV_IGK`**: (Boolean) Represents the status of the ignition key. `TRUE` typically means ignition is ON, `FALSE` means ignition is OFF.
*   **`LV_FRS_ERR_CAN`**: (Boolean) Indicates if an error is detected in the Fuel Reserve Signal received via the CAN bus. `TRUE` means an error is present.
*   **`LV_FRS_CAN`**: (Boolean/Value) The actual Fuel Reserve Signal value received from the instrument cluster (ICL) over the CAN bus.
*   **`C_T_IGK_ON_FRS_CAN_DIAG`**: (Time Constant) A predefined constant value representing a diagnostic time delay related to the Fuel Reserve Signal and CAN communication, specifically when the ignition is ON.
*   **Internal `LV_FRS`**: (Boolean) The current or last calculated/stored state of the "Last Valid Fuel Reserve Signal". This acts as both an input (feedback) and an output within the main calculation block.
*   **Internal `T_DLY_FRS_DIAG_CAN`**: (Time Value) A timer or delay counter for diagnostic purposes related to the Fuel Reserve Signal from CAN. This is initialized and used in calculations.

## Outputs

The main calculated output of the system is:

*   **`opm`**: (Boolean/Value) The final, determined Fuel Reserve Signal, ready for use by other systems or for display to the driver.

Additionally, the internal states that are passed around or potentially stored as global variables are also outputted from the main calculation block:

*   **`<LV_IGK>`**
*   **`<LV_FRS_ERR_CAN>`**
*   **`<LV_FRS_CAN>`**
*   **`<T_DLY_FRS_DIAG_CAN>`**
*   **`<LV_FRS>`**

## Logic Flow

The logical flow of the system is divided into initialization phases and a continuous calculation phase:

### 1. Initialization at ECU Reset (Figure 44.4.3: RST)

*   **Event**: When the ECU undergoes a reset.
*   **Action 1**: The internal signal `<LV_FRS>` (Last Valid Fuel Reserve Signal) is initialized to `FALSE`. This likely sets a safe or default state upon system startup, indicating no active fuel reserve condition or an unknown state requiring re-evaluation.
*   **Action 2**: The diagnostic time delay `<T_DLY_FRS_DIAG_CAN>` is initialized to the value of the constant `C_T_IGK_ON_FRS_CAN_DIAG`. This resets the diagnostic timer.

### 2. Initialization at Ignition Key OFF to ON (Figure 44.4.4: IGKON)

*   **Event**: When the ignition key (`IGK`) transitions from OFF to ON.
*   **Action**: The diagnostic time delay `<T_DLY_FRS_DIAG_CAN>` is re-initialized to the value of the constant `C_T_IGK_ON_FRS_CAN_DIAG`. This ensures the diagnostic timer is restarted with each new ignition cycle.

### 3. Fuel Reserve Signal Calculation (Main Logic - Figure 44.4.5: OPM)

This is the continuous calculation phase, described by the OPM block and its accompanying text (44.4.2.1 "Calculation in 1 sec grid"). This logic determines the final `opm` signal based on various conditions:

*   **Rule 1: Normal Operation (Ignition ON, No CAN Error)**
    *   **Condition**: If `LV_IGK` is `TRUE` (ignition key is ON) AND `LV_FRS_ERR_CAN` is `FALSE` (no CAN error detected for the Fuel Reserve Signal).
    *   **Action**: The internal `LV_FRS` (Last Valid Fuel Reserve Signal) is directly updated with the value of `LV_FRS_CAN` (the signal received from the instrument cluster via CAN). This means in normal conditions, the system trusts the CAN signal from the cluster.

*   **Rule 2: CAN Error with Elapsed Diagnostic Delay (Ignition ON)**
    *   **Condition**: If `LV_IGK` is `TRUE` (ignition key is ON) AND `T_DLY_FRS_DIAG_CAN` has elapsed (indicated by `0 sec` or a specific condition related to its counting down) AND `LV_FRS_ERR_CAN` is `TRUE` (a CAN error is detected for the Fuel Reserve Signal).
    *   **Action**: The internal `LV_FRS` is forced to `TRUE` (or `1`).

*   **Action**: The internal `LV_FRS` is forced to `TRUE` (or `1`). This acts as a fail-safe mechanism: if there's an ongoing CAN error and the diagnostic delay has passed, the system assumes a "fuel low" or "reserve active" state to proactively warn the driver.

*   **Rule 3: Ignition OFF (Hold Last Valid State)**
    *   **Condition**: If `LV_IGK` is `FALSE` (ignition key is OFF).
    *   **Action**: The internal `LV_FRS` retains its last known valid value. This prevents the fuel reserve signal from changing or being invalidated while the vehicle is not in operation.

The final output `opm` is the result of these continuous calculations, reflecting the current determined fuel reserve status based on the defined logic and input conditions.

## Function
The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to determine the state of a "Fuel Reserve Signal" (`<LV_FRS>`) for an automotive system. It combines inputs from diagnostic channels, CAN bus error and status signals, and the ignition key status (`<LV_IGK>`). The logic includes handling for diagnostic delays, CAN communication errors, and a specific behavior to retain the last known fuel reserve state when the ignition is switched off. The overall goal is to provide a robust and reliable fuel reserve indicator.

## Inputs
1.  **`<T_DLY_FRS_DIAG_CAN>`**: Fuel Reserve Signal Diagnostic from CAN (raw, likely a boolean or numerical value indicating a reserve condition).
2.  **`<LV_IGK>`**: Ignition Key Status (boolean, typically TRUE when ignition is ON).
3.  **`<LV_FRS_ERR_CAN>`**: Fuel Reserve Signal Error from CAN (likely an integer, where 0 indicates no error).
4.  **`<LV_FRS_CAN>`**: Fuel Reserve Signal received via CAN (likely a boolean).
5.  **`<LV_FRS>`**: Previous state of the Fuel Reserve Signal (feedback, used for state retention).

## Outputs
1.  **`<T_DLY_FRS_DIAG_CAN>`**: A delayed version of the input diagnostic signal. This might be used by other modules requiring a stabilized or synchronized diagnostic input.
2.  **`<LV_FRS>`**: The final, processed Fuel Reserve Signal (boolean, indicating if the reserve condition is active).

## Logic Flow

The logic flow can be broken down into several parallel and conditional paths that ultimately converge to produce the final `<LV_FRS>` output. The `Merge` block (`V.6.2`) indicates that only one of its input paths is active at any given time, dictated by the upstream conditional logic.

2.  **Ignition Key State Derivation:**

6.  **Final Fuel Reserve Signal (`<LV_FRS>`) Output:**

## Function
The primary function of these Simulink diagrams is to manage the Non-Volatile Memory (NVM) parameters for an automotive system, specifically for "Fuel tank level functional diagnosis" (FUTL). Two distinct NVM handling processes are depicted:

1.  **Initialization with Default (Figure 44.7.11):** This process is executed when the system starts or when the NVM is determined to be empty or corrupted. It attempts to read stored values from NVM for a set of diagnostic parameters. If a read operation fails, or if the NVM location is uninitialized, a predefined default value is provided instead.
2.  **Restoration from NVM (Figure 44.7.12):** This process is used to simply read the current state of diagnostic parameters from NVM. It assumes the NVM has been previously initialized and contains valid data, retrieving these values for system operation.

Together, these functions ensure that critical diagnostic parameters persist across ignition cycles and have sensible starting values.

## Inputs
The "inputs" to these diagrams are implicitly the default values associated with each NVM parameter, which are used during the initialization phase if the NVM read fails. For the restoration phase, the inputs are effectively the values stored in the Non-Volatile Memory itself.

Explicit default values visible in the diagram:
*   `FTL_MMV_LPF_OLD`: Initial value `16`
*   `FCO_SUM_RES`: Initial value `0.115331`
*   `FCO_SUM_OLD`: Initial value `0`
*   `CTR_RBM_FTL_GRD_DIAG`: Initial value `0`
*   `CTR_INC_FTL_GRD_DIAG`: Initial value `0`
*   `FTL_BAS_EL_R_MAX`: Initial value `0`
*   `FTL_BAS_EL_R_MIN`: Initial value `0`

## Outputs
The diagrams produce aggregated output buses containing the NVM parameter values after processing.

**From Figure 44.7.11 (`nvmini` bus):**
This bus contains the initialized/default values for the following parameters:
*   `FTL_MMV_LPF_OLD`
*   `FCO_SUM_RES`
*   `FCO_SUM_OLD`
*   `CTR_RBM_FTL_GRD_DIAG`
*   `CTR_INC_FTL_GRD_DIAG`
*   `FTL_BAS_EL_R_MAX`
*   `FTL_BAS_EL_R_MIN`

**From Figure 44.7.12 (`nvmres` bus):**
This bus contains the restored (read) values for the following parameters:
*   `FTL_MMV_LPF_OLD`
*   `FCO_SUM_RES`
*   `FCO_SUM_OLD`
*   `CTR_RBM_FTL_GRD_DIAG`

## Logic Flow

### Figure 44.7.11: Init non volatile memory with default
1.  **Individual NVM Access Blocks:** For each NVM parameter (e.g., `FTL_MMV_LPF_OLD`, `FCO_SUM_RES`, etc.), a dedicated `NVMY[read/init]` block is instantiated.
2.  **Attempt Read and Default Fallback:** Each `NVMY[read/init]` block performs an internal operation:
    *   It attempts to read the corresponding parameter's value from Non-Volatile Memory.
    *   If the read operation is successful and the NVM is valid, the block outputs the stored value.
    *   If the NVM is empty, corrupted, or the read fails for any reason (indicating an uninitialized or faulty NVM entry), the block outputs its predefined `init:` (default) value.
3.  **Signal Routing and Aggregation:** The individual output signals from these `NVMY[read/init]` blocks are then routed through various multiplexers (labeled V.6.8) and subsequently collected.
4.  **Bus Creation (`nvmini`):** All these individual values, representing the NVM parameters initialized either by reading from NVM or by applying defaults, are then combined into a single output bus named `nvmini`. This bus provides the comprehensive set of initialized NVM values to other parts of the system.

### Figure 44.7.12: Restore from non volatile memory
1.  **Individual NVM Access Blocks:** Similar to initialization, a `NVMY[read/init]` block is used for each NVM parameter.
2.  **Read NVM:** In this "restore" context, the primary function of each `NVMY[read/init]` block is to read the current stored value from Non-Volatile Memory. While these blocks still have `init:` values, these would generally not be used in a typical restore operation unless there was a catastrophic NVM failure.
3.  **Signal Routing and Aggregation:** The successfully read values from NVM are routed via multiplexers (V.6.8) as necessary.
4.  **Bus Creation (`nvmres`):** The individual restored values are aggregated into a single output bus named `nvmres`. This bus provides the current state of the NVM parameters as read directly from memory.

## Function

The primary function of this diagram is to determine the activation condition for a "Fuel Tank Level Stuck" diagnostic. It outputs a temporary flag (`<LV_FTL_STUCK_TMP[i]>`) that indicates whether the necessary preconditions are met to run the fuel tank level stuck diagnosis. Essentially, it checks if the diagnosis is not explicitly inhibited and if the fuel tank level, after low-pass filtering, is within a specific, valid operating range.

## Inputs

*   **`<LV_INH_ERR_FTL_STUCK[i]>`**: (Boolean) - "Level Inhibit Error Fuel Tank Level Stuck". This input likely indicates if there's an active inhibition or an error preventing the fuel tank level stuck diagnosis from running.
*   **`<FTL_STUCK_LPF[i]>`**: (Numerical) - "Fuel Tank Level Stuck Low-Pass Filtered". This is a smoothed or averaged value of the fuel tank level, used for robust comparison.
*   **`<C_FTL_MIN_STUCK[i]>`**: (Numerical Constant) - "Constant Fuel Tank Level Minimum Stuck". This defines the lower boundary of the fuel tank level range within which the stuck diagnosis should be active.
*   **`<C_FTL_MAX_STUCK[i]>`**: (Numerical Constant) - "Constant Fuel Tank Level Maximum Stuck". This defines the upper boundary of the fuel tank level range within which the stuck diagnosis should be active.

## Outputs

*   **`<LV_FTL_STUCK_TMP[i]>`**: (Boolean) - "Level Fuel Tank Level Stuck Temporary". This output is a temporary flag or an activation condition. It becomes true when all the necessary conditions for the "Fuel Tank Level Stuck" diagnosis are met.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Inhibition Check (NOT gate V.6.8):** The boolean input `<LV_INH_ERR_FTL_STUCK[i]>` is passed through a NOT gate. This means the output of V.6.8 will be TRUE only if the diagnosis is *not* inhibited (i.e., `<LV_INH_ERR_FTL_STUCK[i]>` is FALSE). If the diagnosis is inhibited (`<LV_INH_ERR_FTL_STUCK[i]>` is TRUE), the output of V.6.8 will be FALSE.

2.  **Minimum Level Check (GreaterThanOrEqual block V.6.6):** The low-pass filtered fuel tank level `<FTL_STUCK_LPF[i]>` is compared against the minimum stuck threshold `<C_FTL_MIN_STUCK[i]>`. The output of V.6.6 is TRUE if the filtered fuel level is greater than or equal to the minimum threshold, indicating the level is above the lower operating limit for the diagnosis.

3.  **Maximum Level Check (LessThanOrEqual block V.6.9):** The low-pass filtered fuel tank level `<FTL_STUCK_LPF[i]>` is compared against the maximum stuck threshold `<C_FTL_MAX_STUCK[i]>`. The output of V.6.9 is TRUE if the filtered fuel level is less than or equal to the maximum threshold, indicating the level is below the upper operating limit for the diagnosis.

4.  **Combine Conditions (AND gate V.6.10):** The outputs from the NOT gate (V.6.8), the GreaterThanOrEqual block (V.6.6), and the LessThanOrEqual block (V.6.9) are all fed into an AND gate. The AND gate (V.6.10) will output TRUE only if *all three* of its inputs are TRUE. This means:
    *   The diagnosis is *not* inhibited.
    *   The low-pass filtered fuel tank level is *greater than or equal to* the minimum allowed level.
    *   The low-pass filtered fuel tank level is *less than or equal to* the maximum allowed level.

5.  **Output Flag:** The output of the AND gate (V.6.10) directly sets the state of `<LV_FTL_STUCK_TMP[i]>`. Therefore, `<LV_FTL_STUCK_TMP[i]>` will be TRUE when the diagnosis is permitted and the filtered fuel tank level falls within the specified range [C_FTL_MIN_STUCK, C_FTL_MAX_STUCK]. This flag serves as an enablement condition for further diagnostic steps for detecting a stuck fuel tank level sensor.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to determine if the fuel tank level signal is "stuck" within a defined hysteresis window around a previously memorized mean value. It provides two independent mechanisms for this detection: one based on the raw electrical sensor signal and another based on the fuel tank level converted to liters. A control signal then selects which of these detection mechanisms is currently active to produce the final "stuck" symptom output.

## Inputs

*   **`FTL_BAS_EL_R[i]`**: Raw electrical value from the fuel tank level sensor. The `[i]` suggests it could be an indexed signal, possibly for multiple sensors or multiple states/channels.
*   **`C_FTL_MMV_EL_HYS[i]`**: Hysteresis constant for the electrical fuel tank level value.
*   **`FTL_MMV_EL_INI[i]`**: Memorized mean or initial value for the electrical fuel tank level.
*   **`FTL_BAS[i]`**: Converted fuel tank level value in liters.
*   **`C_FTL_MMV_HYS[i]`**: Hysteresis constant for the converted fuel tank level value in liters.
*   **`FTL_MMV_INI[i]`**: Memorized mean or initial value for the converted fuel tank level in liters.
*   **`LC_FTL_STUCK_EL_ENA`**: A logical control signal (enable/disable) that selects whether the electrical signal-based stuck detection or the liter-based stuck detection is used.

## Outputs

*   **`LV_SYM_FTL_STUCK_TMP[i]`**: A temporary diagnostic variable (likely a boolean flag) indicating whether the fuel tank level signal (either electrical or liter, depending on the `LC_FTL_STUCK_EL_ENA` input) is detected as stuck.

## Logic Flow

The diagram consists of two parallel detection branches and a final selection logic.

**1. Electrical Signal Stuck Detection Branch (Upper Branch):**
    *   **Hysteresis Upper Bound Check**: The current raw electrical sensor value (`FTL_BAS_EL_R[i]`) is compared to an upper threshold. This threshold is calculated by adding the electrical hysteresis constant (`C_FTL_MMV_EL_HYS[i]`) to the memorized electrical mean value (`FTL_MMV_EL_INI[i]`). If `FTL_BAS_EL_R[i]` is *less than* this sum, the output is true. This checks if the signal is below the upper bound of the "stuck" window.
    *   **Hysteresis Lower Bound Check**: The current raw electrical sensor value (`FTL_BAS_EL_R[i]`) is compared to a lower threshold. This threshold is calculated by subtracting the electrical hysteresis constant (`C_FTL_MMV_EL_HYS[i]`) from the memorized electrical mean value (`FTL_MMV_EL_INI[i]`).

This checks if the signal is below the upper bound of the "stuck" window.
    *   **Hysteresis Lower Bound Check**: The current raw electrical sensor value (`FTL_BAS_EL_R[i]`) is compared to a lower threshold. This threshold is calculated by subtracting the electrical hysteresis constant (`C_FTL_MMV_EL_HYS[i]`) from the memorized electrical mean value (`FTL_MMV_EL_INI[i]`). If `FTL_BAS_EL_R[i]` is *greater than* this difference, the output is true. This checks if the signal is above the lower bound of the "stuck" window.
    *   **AND Logic**: The outputs from the upper and lower bound checks are fed into an `AND` gate. If both conditions are true (i.e., the `FTL_BAS_EL_R[i]` is simultaneously less than the upper bound AND greater than the lower bound), it means the raw electrical signal is currently *within* the defined hysteresis window. This output represents a potential "stuck" condition for the electrical signal.

**2. Converted Liter Signal Stuck Detection Branch (Lower Branch):**
    *   This branch operates identically to the electrical signal branch but uses the converted fuel tank level in liters (`FTL_BAS[i]`) and its corresponding hysteresis (`C_FTL_MMV_HYS[i]`) and memorized mean (`FTL_MMV_INI[i]`) values.
    *   **Hysteresis Upper Bound Check**: `FTL_BAS[i]` < (`FTL_MMV_INI[i]` + `C_FTL_MMV_HYS[i]`).
    *   **Hysteresis Lower Bound Check**: `FTL_BAS[i]` > (`FTL_MMV_INI[i]` - `C_FTL_MMV_HYS[i]`).
    *   **AND Logic**: The outputs from these two comparisons are combined using an `AND` gate. If both are true, it indicates that the converted liter value is currently *within* its defined hysteresis window, representing a potential "stuck" condition for the liter signal.

**3. Final Output Selection (Switch Block):**
    *   A `Switch` block takes the potential "stuck" condition from the electrical branch (upper input) and the liter branch (lower input) as its data inputs.
    *   The `LC_FTL_STUCK_EL_ENA` signal is connected to the control port of the `Switch` block.
    *   Based on the label "Check ~= 0", if `LC_FTL_STUCK_EL_ENA` is true (or non-zero), the `Switch` block passes the output from the **electrical signal stuck detection branch** to the final output.
    *   If `LC_FTL_STUCK_EL_ENA` is false (or zero), the `Switch` block passes the output from the **converted liter signal stuck detection branch** to the final output.
    *   The selected boolean value is then assigned to the output signal `LV_SYM_FTL_STUCK_TMP[i]`.

### Part 2: Calculation (Figure 44.7.39) - (Detailed logic for a single sensor's FTL gradient check, likely representing sub-system X.3.1.1.1)

1.  **Inhibition Check:** The `<LV_INH_ERR_FTL_GRD[0]>` signal is passed through a `NOT` gate. This means the condition will be true if the error is *not* inhibited.

2.  **Upper Limit Check:** The filtered fuel level measured value (`<FTL_MMV_LPF[0]>`) is compared with the maximum gradient threshold (`<C_FTL_MAX_GRD[0]>`) using a "less than or equal to" (`<=`) operator. This checks if the value is within or below the upper limit.

3.  **Lower Limit Check:** The filtered fuel level measured value (`<FTL_MMV_LPF[0]>`) is compared with the minimum gradient threshold (`<C_FTL_MIN_GRD[0]>`) using a "greater than or equal to" (`>=`) operator. This checks if the value is within or above the lower limit.

4.  **Combined Condition:** The outputs of the `NOT` gate (inhibition status), the upper limit check, and the lower limit check are fed into an `AND` gate. This means all three conditions must be met for the output to be true:
    *   The error is *not* inhibited (`NOT LV_INH_ERR_FTL_GRD[0]`).
    *   The measured value is not above the maximum gradient (`FTL_MMV_LPF[0] <= C_FTL_MAX_GRD[0]`).
    *   The measured value is not below the minimum gradient (`FTL_MMV_LPF[0] >= C_FTL_MIN_GRD[0]`).

5.  **Diagnostic Output Assignment:** The boolean result of the `AND` gate controls a selection block. ## Function
This Simulink diagram, titled "FUTL Fuel tank level functional diagnosis", is designed to perform diagnostic checks on the fuel tank level (FTL) system. Its primary function is to detect implausible fuel tank level readings or rates of change, which could indicate issues such as sensor malfunctions, calculation errors, or abnormal fuel consumption (as hinted by the accompanying text "Fuel consumption of FTL is too low or too high"). It evaluates various conditions and, based on these, updates internal diagnostic states and outputs a status indicating the overall condition check result.

## Inputs
The diagram receives the following inputs:

*   **`<FTL_MMV_LPF_OLD[i]>`**: The previous (old) low-pass filtered moving median value of the fuel tank level, likely representing a historical state for comparison.
*   **`<FTL_MMV_LPF[i]>`**: The current low-pass filtered moving median value of the fuel tank level.
*   **`<C_FTL_MMV_MIN[i]>`**: A calibrated constant representing the minimum acceptable threshold for the FTL moving median value.
*   **`<C_FTL_MMV_MAX[i]>`**: A calibrated constant representing the maximum acceptable threshold for the FTL moving median value.
*   **`<FTL_BAS_EL_R_MAX[i]>`**: The maximum base electrical resistance reading from the FTL sensor.
*   **`<FTL_BAS_EL_R_MIN[i]>`**: The minimum base electrical resistance reading from the FTL sensor.
*   **`<C_FTL_BAS_EL_R_DIF[i]>`**: A calibrated constant representing the minimum acceptable difference between the max and min FTL base electrical resistance.
*   **`<C_CTR_MAX_FTL_GRD_DIAG>`**: A calibrated constant representing the maximum counter value for FTL gradient diagnosis.
*   **`<CTR_INC_FTL_GRD_DIAG[i]>`**: A diagnostic counter for FTL gradient, which is also an output/feedback signal.
*   **`<LV_SYM_FTL_GRD[i]>`**: A local variable representing the symmetrical FTL gradient, also an output/feedback signal.
*   **`<STATE_FIL_FTL_GRD[i]>`**: A state variable representing the filtered FTL gradient, also an output/feedback signal.

## Outputs
The primary output of this specific subsystem for external usage is:

*   **`cdn_chk`**: A "condition check" output, likely a boolean (true/false) or an enumeration indicating the diagnostic status (e.g., OK, Error, Warning).

Internal signals that are updated and potentially passed on as state for the next iteration or as part of a larger output bus include:
*   **`<CTR_INC_FTL_GRD_DIAG[i]>`**
*   **`<LV_SYM_FTL_GRD[i]>`**
*   **`FTL_MMV_LPF_OLD[i]`**
*   **`<STATE_FIL_FTL_GRD[i]>`**

## Logic Flow

The logic flow can be broken down into two main stages: condition evaluation and state update/action.

**1. Condition Evaluation (Top Section)**

*   **FTL Moving Median Value Range Check**:
    *   The previous filtered FTL value (`<FTL_MMV_LPF_OLD[i]>`) is compared using a less-than operator (`<`, V.6.6) with a minimum threshold (`<C_FTL_MMV_MIN[i]>`). This checks if the historical value is too low.
    *   The current filtered FTL value (`<FTL_MMV_LPF[i]>`) is compared using a greater-than operator (`>`, V.6.6) with a maximum threshold (`<C_FTL_MMV_MAX[i]>`). This checks if the current value is too high.
    *   The results of these two comparisons are fed into an `OR` gate (V.6.7). If either the old value is below its minimum *OR* the current value is above its maximum, this part of the condition evaluates to true.

*   **FTL Base Electrical Resistance Difference Check**:
    *   The maximum (`<FTL_BAS_EL_R_MAX[i]>`) and minimum (`<FTL_BAS_EL_R_MIN[i]>`) FTL base electrical resistance readings are subtracted from each other.
    *   The resulting difference is then compared using a less-than operator (`<`, V.6.6) with a calibrated difference threshold (`<C_FTL_BAS_EL_R_DIF[i]>`).

*   **FTL Base Electrical Resistance Difference Check**:
    *   The maximum (`<FTL_BAS_EL_R_MAX[i]>`) and minimum (`<FTL_BAS_EL_R_MIN[i]>`) FTL base electrical resistance readings are subtracted from each other.
    *   The resulting difference is then compared using a less-than operator (`<`, V.6.6) with a calibrated difference threshold (`<C_FTL_BAS_EL_R_DIF[i]>`). This likely checks if the sensor's range of readings is implausibly small, indicating a potential stuck sensor or wiring issue.

*   **Overall Error Condition Determination**:
    *   The output of the `OR` gate (from the MMV range check) and the output of the electrical resistance difference check are combined using an `AND` gate (V.6.10). This implies that an "error" is triggered only if *both* the FTL moving median value is out of its expected range *AND* the FTL sensor's electrical resistance difference is below its minimum threshold.
    *   The result of this `AND` gate (`cond_if`) is fed into an `If` block (V.6.4). If `cond_if` is true, the 'error' path is activated; otherwise, the 'no_error' path is activated.

**2. State Update and Diagnostic Action (Bottom Section)**

*   **Conditional Function Execution**:
    *   Based on the `If` block's decision:
        *   If the error condition is met (`[error]` path), a custom function block labeled "ERROR X.3.1.2.1.3.1.2.1" is executed.
        *   If no error condition is met (`[no_error]` path), a custom function block labeled "NO_ERROR X.3.1.2.1.3.1.2.2" is executed.

*   **Function Block Operations**:
    *   Both function blocks (`f()`) take a bus of input signals, including the current FTL MMV, diagnostic counter thresholds, and existing state variables for FTL gradient and old LPF values.
    *   The "ERROR" function likely increments error counters (e.g., `<CTR_INC_FTL_GRD_DIAG[i]>`), updates FTL gradient states (`<LV_SYM_FTL_GRD[i]>`, `<STATE_FIL_FTL_GRD[i]>`) to reflect an anomalous condition, and might propagate the `FTL_MMV_LPF_OLD[i]` value.
    *   The "NO_ERROR" function, conversely, would likely reset or decrement error counters, update FTL gradient states to reflect a normal condition, and update `FTL_MMV_LPF_OLD[i]` with the current filtered value for the next cycle.
    *   These function blocks compute the updated values for the various feedback signals.

*   **Output Merging and Final Status**:
    *   The outputs from the active function block (either "ERROR" or "NO_ERROR") are directed to a `BusMerge` block (V.6.6). This block collects all the updated state variables and other relevant diagnostic signals into a single output bus.
    *   From this merged bus, the final system output `cdn_chk` is derived. This signal represents the overall health or diagnostic status of the fuel tank level system based on the evaluations performed in this diagram.

## Function

The primary function of this system is to perform a functional diagnosis for a Fuel Tank Level (FTL) sensor, particularly identifying potential grounding issues. It operates in two main modes:
1.  **Normal Diagnostic Mode (Figure 44.753):** In this mode, it continuously monitors the FTL sensor's low-pass filtered value, increments a counter if a specific condition (likely related to the grounding issue) persists, and declares a "FAIL" state if the counter reaches a predefined maximum threshold. It also updates a symbolic flag for the grounding status and stores the previous FTL value.
2.  **"Condition Not OK" Mode (Figure 44.754):** This mode acts as a reset or default state. When a higher-level "condition not ok" is active, it resets the diagnostic counter, sets the grounding status flag to a default '0', and sets the diagnostic state to "PASS", effectively deactivating or overriding the active diagnosis.

It also updates a symbolic flag for the grounding status and stores the previous FTL value.
2.  **"Condition Not OK" Mode (Figure 44.754):** This mode acts as a reset or default state. When a higher-level "condition not ok" is active, it resets the diagnostic counter, sets the grounding status flag to a default '0', and sets the diagnostic state to "PASS", effectively deactivating or overriding the active diagnosis.

## Inputs

The key inputs to this combined system are:

*   **`<FTL_MMV_LPF[i]>`**: The current low-pass filtered measurement value from the Fuel Tank Level sensor. (Analog value)
*   **`<CTR_INC_FTL_GRD_DIAG[i]>`**: The previous or current value of the incrementing counter used for the FTL grounding diagnosis. (Integer)
*   **`<C_CTR_MAX_FTL_GRD_DIAG>`**: A configurable constant representing the maximum threshold for the incrementing counter. (Integer)
*   **(Implicit) "Condition Not OK" Flag**: An external control signal or logical state that determines which of the two diagrams' logic (Figure 44.753 or Figure 44.754) is active. This signal is implied by the titles of the figures.
*   **(Implicit) "Check == 0" Signal (V.6.10)**: A control signal for switch blocks that may determine if calculated values are passed through or if an alternative path (e.g., holding value, resetting) is taken.

## Outputs

The key outputs from this combined system are:

*   **`<LV_SYM_FTL_GRD[i]>`**: A logical or symbolic variable indicating the current status of the FTL sensor grounding. (e.g., Boolean or Enum)
*   **`<FTL_MMV_LPF_OLD[i]>`**: The value of the low-pass filtered FTL measurement from the previous time step. This acts as a stored state. (Analog value)
*   **`<CTR_INC_FTL_GRD_DIAG[i]>`**: The updated value of the incrementing counter for the FTL grounding diagnosis. (Integer)
*   **`<STATE_FIL_FTL_GRD[i]>`**: The filtered diagnostic state for FTL grounding, which can indicate "FAIL", "NO_EVE" (No Event), or "PASS". (Enum or symbolic)

## Logic Flow

The system's logic flow depends on an overarching "condition not ok" flag, which determines the active operational mode:

**Scenario 1: "Condition Not OK" is Active (Logic from Figure 44.754)**

This scenario represents a "safe" or "default" state, often triggered by a higher-priority system fault or an invalid operating condition for diagnosis.
1.  **FTL Grounding Symbol (`<LV_SYM_FTL_GRD[i]>`)**: The output is directly set to `0`.
